Until now, few individuals other than a very few poets, painters, musicians and certain
commercial uses have sefously tried to cope with the new art forms involved in these new
media. Education has generally not examined their true nature and possibilities. Yet
today the new media have become an integral factor in our global co-existence, for which
education should be training our citizens •
HI. Objectives: To develop a manual and syntax for basic training of media perception
and judgement in the schools, with emphasis on television and radio. Since all media,
from the phonetic alphabet to television, are inseparable from the development of the arts,
sciences and social institutions, it will obviously eventually be necessary to correlate
media training with almost every aspect of the existing curricula and the procedures asso¬
ciated with them, much as reading, writing and English are treated today, particularly in
elementary and secondary education. All current experiments with these new media would
